Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Novel Designs for Kidney Exchange and Other Markets, in the Intersection of Operations Research, Economics and Computer Science

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) Program award is the design, study and implementation of algorithms and matching mechanisms for kidney exchange and other matching markets. In the last decade the field of market design has been growing rapidly, attracting economists, operations researchers and computer scientists. The emergence of kidney exchange clearinghouses is one of the successes of this field. The need for kidney exchange arises when someone who wishes to donate a kidney to a particular recipient is incompatible with that recipient. Two or more incompatible pairs can participate in an exchange allowing the patients to receive transplants. The growth of kidney exchange clearinghouses has driven novel theory based on empirical evidence, leading to impact on existing mechanisms. However, the growth is still slow leaving many more questions than answers. Long term efficiency in kidney exchange will be studied with emphasis on developing and analyzing dynamic mechanisms driven by data. As many exchanges fail to take place in practice (due to hospitals? preferences and medical issues), to reduce failures as well as developing mechanisms that will increase efficiency in the presence of such failures will be investigated. The potential growth of kidney exchange will be studied, from merging exchange networks (domestically and internationally) to relaxing current constraints such as conducting exchanges simultaneously. Finally, unresolved issues in driven by actual challenges in other matching markets will be investigated.

There are over 92,000 patients on the waiting list for cadaver kidneys in the U.S and there is a severe shortage of kidneys for transplant; In 2011, 33,581 patients were added to the waiting list, 11,026 transplants from cadaver and 5,154 transplants from living donors were performed, 4,700 patients died and 2,466 were "Too Sick to Transplant". Kidney exchange is therefore a growing source for living donation. Expanding kidney exchange will help many people.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant has developed theoretical and practical contribubtions in the the context of organ allocation and matchign markets more generally. Some of the main findings are described below.

One extended area this grant supported is kidney exchange. Kidney exchange  allows swaps between patient-donor incompatible pairs and now  accounts for about 12 precent  of live donor transplants.The growth of kidney exchange has  involved many operational and design challenges in order to maximize the number of transplants.  The first challenge  this work addresses is how should a platform match over time given that waiting is costly for patients but at the same time increases mach oppurtunities. We study this trade-off and in fact identify that greedy policies are typically optimal. The second challenge is to create  collaborations between hospitals. After a decade  since the launch of kidney exchange platforms, we identified that there are market failures that cause the loss of hundreds of transplants per year: more that half of the exchanges are facilitated  within hospitals rather  than through national platforms. Within-hospital exchanges often use easier-to-match pairs, leaving national platforms with mostly hard-to-match pairs.  We  developed a simple point-based mechanisms to encourage hospital participation on platform based on their marginal contribution. Such a system is now in at least one national platform.

This grant also suppoerted basic research on two-sided matching markets. Stable matching theory has been instrumental in the study and design of two-sided markets. The  literature traditionally studies whether good properties can be guaranteed for any preference realization.This line of research led to  negative results and further provides almost no link  between market characteristics and stable outcomes.By adopting  a stochastic approach,  we have addressed  several fundamental issues in matching markets, establishing that  desired  properties hold  with high probability. I find that  matching markets generally have a small core,and realizations with multiple stable matchings are only a knife-edge case. This solves a longstanding puzzle explaining why empirically small cores are ubiquitous. Practically this means that  in centralized marketplaces like the NRMP it is irrelevant what stable matching algorithm is implemented, and, it is also safe torecommend all agents  to act sincerely.In this work I also find matching markets to be  extremely competitive: agents on the short side match with very top choices andagents on the long side match almost with a random partner.

 

This grant has also supported  research on school choice, and application of matching markets, both theoretically and practiclly. A major concern in Boston  was  unsustainable busing costs, representing 10% of the total school board budget. Prior to  2014, the city was divided into three ``zones" and families could  rank schools within their zone.  We developed theory for  allocating optimally heterogeneous services to agents  under incomplete information and further find that the solution has a simple and transplanrent implementation. Applying  to Boston data, the solution outperforms the existing design with respect to  efficiency, equity, and predictability.  Another challenge in school choice systmes is how to use   lotteries in order to resolve ties between students  in schools with excess demand. Motivated by debates in NYC, Chile and Amsterdam, we compare two common tie-breaking rules: either all schools  use a  common lottery, or each school uses a separate  lottery. Separate lotteries  seem fairer but may create artificial inefficiencies. We find that a single lottery stochastically dominates multiple lotteries in overdemanded schools. This  removes the confusion in early discussions ands uggests that  popular schools should use a common lottery.
